revised_title: Bactericidal Action of Ultra-Violet Radiations in Arc Spectra
tldr: The authors conducted experiments to determine the effect of exposure to arc spectra of carbon and various metals on the vitality of bacteria. They found that the bactericidal action was entirely confined to the ultra-violet region, with the active radiations lying between wave-lengths 3287 and 2265. The study concluded that the bactericidal action of light is almost entirely due to the action of ultra-violet radiations in this region, and that any source of light used as a bactericidal agent should be rich in these rays.
